website_content.content:
The aftermath in the departures hall at Brussels Zaventem airport following the explosions
Bombings at Brussels airport and a metro station in the city on Tuesday 22 March killed 32 people from around the world. 
Many more were injured in the attacks. The toll does not include three bombers who died. 
Twin blasts struck the main terminal of Zaventem international airport, in the north-east of the city. 
Another explosion hit the Maelbeek metro station in the city centre, close to several European Union institutions.
This video can not be played
Brussels explosions: Timeline of events
The so-called Islamic State group said it was behind the attacks.
CCTV footage captured the three attackers shortly before two of them detonated explosives
The bombers have been named as follows:
Khalid el-Bakraoui (deceased) - identified by the Belgian federal prosecutor as the suicide bomber in the metro attack. Khalid, 27, had used a false name to rent the flat in the Forest area of the Belgian capital where police killed a gunman in a shootout on 15 March.
Osama K- Prosecutors say this man, arrested on 8 April, has been identified as the man seen with Bakraoui at the Malbeek metro station, and that he bought bags used by the attackers at Zaventem airport. He has been identified in media reports as Swedish national Osama...[Content truncated]

website_quality_evaluation.justification: The BBC is a globally recognized news organization known for its rigorous journalistic standards and commitment to impartiality. It has a reputation for providing accurate reporting and has a long history of fact-checking and a robust editorial system. Though occasionally criticized for bias, its adherence to journalistic ethics lends it high credibility in news reporting.

Relevance.Relevance Justification: This evidence provides a clear context of the bombings at Brussels Airport on March 22, 2016, detailing the aftermath of the explosions and confirming that they were terrorist attacks that resulted in numerous casualties. It mentions CCTV footage capturing suspects before the explosions, supporting the authenticity of media surrounding the attacks. This strongly relates to the claim and video in question.

metatags.og:title: In Photos: The Explosions in Brussels
metatags.og:description: Blasts in the city’s airport and a subway station have killed dozens and injured many more.

website_content.content:
Explosions in Belgium’s capital struck an airport and a subway station, killing  many more. The  at Zaventem Airport went off at approximately 8 a.m. local time, followed an hour later by a blast at Maelbeek metro station, which is close to the main buildings that house the European Union. Belgium has raised its terrorism threat to the highest level. All flights to Brussels were cancelled, according to the BBC, and Eurostar has cancelled all service to and from the city. So far, no group has claimed responsibility for the attacks, but Prime Minister Charles Michel said the attack at the airport was caused by  The blasts took place less than a week after the capture of , the man authorities believe planned the Paris attacks.
**Hints:** View this page . Skip to the next and previous photo by typing j/k or ←/→.
*        !
    People wrapped in blankets leave the scene of explosions at Zaventem Airport near Brussels, Belgium, March 22, 2016. 
    Francois Lenoir / Reuters
*        !
    In this image taken from TV, an injured person is evacuated as emergency services attend the scene after an explosion in a main metro station in Brussels on Tuesday, March 22, 2016. 
    AP
*        !
   ...[Content truncated]

website_quality_evaluation.justification: The Atlantic is known for high-quality journalism and in-depth reporting on a variety of topics, including culture, politics, and global issues. It has earned respect for its investigative work and provides thoughtful analysis. However, as a magazine, it may intersperse commentary with fact-based reporting, which could lead to some perceived bias.

Relevance.Relevance Justification: The evidence discusses the blasts at the Brussels airport and the chaos they caused, including details about the timing and location of the explosions. Although it does not directly confirm the specific video in question, it corroborates that significant footage exists related to the attack, making it relevant to understanding the context of the claim.

It provides a mix of news and analysis but has been critiqued for occasionally reflecting the biases inherent in state-affiliated media. Overall, it maintains a reasonable standard of accuracy.

website_content.content:
[Content truncated]... move the officials said appeared to be planned.
Taxi driver tip sparks raid
---------------------------
A break in the investigation may have come from a taxi driver who took the suspects to the airport.
The driver contacted authorities after seeing surveillance footage and gave them the address where he picked the men up, according to two U.S. officials briefed on the investigation.
That information prompted authorities to raid a residence after the attacks, the officials said.
Investigators found a nail bomb, chemical products and an ISIS flag during a house search in the northeast Brussels neighborhood of Schaerbeek, Belgium’s federal prosecutor said in a statement.
Hours later, they were still combing through the building for evidence.
Security was high. At one point, a helicopter hovered overhead, carrying a sniper with a weapon trained on the building.
As masked, armed officers stood guard outside the building, the burst of camera flashes inside could be seen from the street below. Officers left the building carrying bags of evidence they loaded onto vehicles.
Ties to Paris attacks?
----------------------
A Belgian government representative told CNN that 10 people were killed and 100 wounded at Brussels’ international airport. At least 20 people died and 130 were wounded at the Maelbeek metro station, officials said.
The blasts sent wounded people fleeing into the streets, spurred evacuations of nuclear plants and transit hubs and led to raids in some areas as authorities searched for suspects and evidence.

website_quality_evaluation.justification: CNN is one of the largest news networks globally and has the resources for extensive coverage. However, it has faced both praise and criticism regarding its reporting accuracy and perceived bias, particularly in politically charged contexts. While CNN has established credibility, concerns about sensationalistic reporting reduce its overall score.

Relevance.Relevance Justification: This evidence describes the immediate aftermath of the explosions, including a traveler running through smoke-filled terminals. Although it doesn't verify the specific video discussed, it provides a vivid illustration of the chaos occurring at Brussels Airport, thereby enhancing the understanding of the context of the video claim.

website_content.content:
Authorities believed the two explosives that went off were in suitcases as well.
— -- During a raid in the Brussels neighborhood of Schaerbeek, police found an "explosive device containing nails," "chemical products" and "an ISIS flag."
A third explosive that did not go off at the Brussels airport was inside a suitcase.
ISIS-linked website says terror group claimed credit for deadly attack, while police seek a suspect
At least 31 people have been confirmed dead in multiple explosions in Brussels, with at least 250 injured, including nine Americans.
Top U.S. lawmakers briefed on the Brussels attacks believe the arrest of Salah Abdeslam accelerated the timetable for the sophisticated series of bombings in Brussels. 

A series of explosions rocked Brussels Tuesday, killing at least 31 and injuring at least 250, including nine Americans in devastating terror attacks for which ISIS took credit.
The explosions, which drew condemnation from world leaders and sparked a cry for solidarity with the Belgian people, took place in Brussels Airport and a subway station near the European Union offices, leaving behind carnage and sending people screaming and running for their lives.
A manhunt was underway Tuesday night for one of the suspected attackers, who was spotted on surveillance video at the airport wearing a white coat. Belgian authorities said that during a raid in the Brussels neighborhood of Schaerbeek, police found an "explosive device containing nails," "chemical products" and "an ISIS flag."
Two devices exploded at the airport and a third, which did not explode, was found in a suitcase, leading authorities to believe the other...[Content truncated]

website_quality_evaluation.justification: ABC News follows generally accepted journalistic standards and provides a range of content from breaking news to in-depth analysis. However, it occasionally faces criticism for bias in specific topics. Overall, it maintains a decent level of reliability.

Relevance.Relevance Justification: This piece of evidence directly discusses the multiple explosions that occurred at the airport and confirms that at least two devices detonated, resulting in many injuries and fatalities. It also mentions surveillance footage capturing the moments leading to the attack, which is crucial for validating or dismissing claims about specific videos related to the attacks.

Belgium Police Release New Video of Brussels Bombing Suspect
share
*   
*   
*   
*

 Breaking News
Belgium Police Release New Video of Brussels Bombing Suspect
============================================================
April 07, 2016 8:23 AM update April 07, 2016 1:43 PM
*   By 
* * *
!
A screengrab of airport CCTV footage released by Belgian federal police shows suspects in the attacks at Brussels Airport, in Zaventem, March 22, 2016. Police is seeking help in identifying the "man in the hat" on the right.
Share
*   
*   
*   
*   
*   
Print
PARIS — Belgian police have released new video of a wanted Brussels airport bombing suspect even as the lawyer for a Paris attacks suspect says his extradition may take a few more weeks.
Released Thursday in French and Flemish, the police video shows the minutes following the March 22 Zaventem Airport bombings and the apparent getaway of the third surviving suspect -- often identified in the media as "the man with the hat."
Local media previously released security camera video of the man at Zaventem Airport shortly before the bombings, wearing a hat and a light jacket and walking alongside suicide bombers Ibrahim el-Bakraoui and Najim Laachraoui. All three men are seen pushing carts with bags on them.
With running commentary in French and Flemish, the police footage shows the third man leaving the airport after the bombs went off at 7:58 a.m. First he is walking, then he breaks into a jog. His face is not seen clearly in the new images.  
**Watch video released by FedPol Belgium:**
We are sorry, but this feature is currently not available
According to Belgian authorities, the man walked more then 10 kilometers in the ensuring hours, crossing the town of Zaventem with video finally showing him in the Schaerbeek area of Brussels, before disappearing at a crossroads at 09:50 local...[Content truncated]

website_quality_evaluation.justification: Voice of America (VOA) provides news with a focus on international audiences, funded by the U.S. government. While it adheres to journalistic standards, its government affiliation might raise questions about objectivity. It does strive for balanced reporting, especially on U.S. perspectives.

Relevance.Relevance Justification: This evidence mentions footage that was released after the bombings. However, it primarily focuses on the suspects and their escape, rather than checking the authenticity of a specific video. Although relevant, it does not contribute significantly to verifying the claim directly.

Death toll rises to 34 in Brussels attacks
==========================================
March 22, 2016 at 5:36 a.m. | Updated March 22, 2016 at 5:40 p.m.
by The Associated Press
!
In this still image taken from video from RTL Belgium people receive treatment in the debris strewn terminal at Brussels Airport, in Brussels after explosions Tuesday, March 22, 2016. Authorities locked down the Belgian capital on Tuesday after explosions rocked the Brussels airport and subway system, killing a number of people and injuring many more. Belgium raised its terror alert to its highest level, diverting arriving planes and trains and ordering people to stay where they were. Airports across Europe tightened security. (RTL via AP)
BRUSSELS — Bombs exploded at the Brussels airport and one of the city's metro stations Tuesday, killing at least 31 people and wounding dozens, as a European capital was again locked down amid heightened security threats. The Islamic State group claimed responsibility for the attacks.
The two airport blasts, at least one of them blamed on a suicide bomber, left behind a chaotic scene of splattered blood in the departure lounge as windows were blown out, ceilings collapsed and travelers streamed out of the smoky building.
About an hour later, another bomb exploded on a rush-hour subway train near the European Union headquarters. Terrified passengers had to evacuate through darkened tunnels to safety.
!  
#### Brussels terror attacks
### *   
### *   
### *   
### *   
"What we feared has happened," Belgian Prime Minister Charles Michel told reporters. "In this time of tragedy, this black moment for our country, I appeal to everyone to remain calm but also to show solidarity."
**\\]**
Belgium raised its terror alert to the highest level, diverting planes and trains and ordering people to stay where they were. Airports across Europe immediately tightened security.
Authorities also released a photo taken from closed-circuit TV of three men pushing luggage carts, saying...[Content truncated]

website_quality_evaluation.justification: This is a regional news website focusing on Arkansas news and issues. As with many local news sources, while it provides valuable community coverage, it may not have the same resources or editorial oversight as larger networks, leading to variations in reliability.

Relevance.Relevance Justification: The details here regarding the bombings at the airport provide strong context and verify that significant violence and chaos were reported on that day. This evidence supports the legitimacy of videos associated with the bombing, although it doesn’t confirm the specific video claim.

Attacker 'really, clearly wanted to kill a Jew'
Brussels airport bombers targeted Jews, Americans, investigators say
====================================================================
Unreleased footage shows one bomber pursuing Orthodox Jews seconds before blasts; unexploded bomb left at United and El Al counters
-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
By  24 January 2017, 5:41 am 
*   
*   
*   
*   (javascript:window.print\(\);)
*   
]
A picture taken off CCTV showing suspects in the Brussels airport attack on March 22, 2016. (Screenshot from YouTube)
BRUSSELS (AFP) — The Islamic State suicide bombers who attacked Brussels airport last year targeted Jewish people and passengers travelling to the United States, several sources told AFP.
The Belgian-led investigation believes a check-in counter for an American carrier was one of the targets in the March 22, 2016 attacks, the sources said on condition of anonymity.
They also suspect that travelers to Israel may have been in the crosshairs. Airport security camera footage shows one bomber apparently pursuing Hasidic Jews seconds before one of the blasts.
Islamic State (IS) bombers Najim Laachraoui and Ibrahim El Bakraoui killed 16 people at Zaventem airport. Around an hour later Bakraoui’s brother Khalid attacked a metro station near EU headquarters, killing another 16.
One source close to the investigation told AFP, which contacted investigators in several countries, that one of the airport bombers “attacked the Delta Airlines check-in”.

“We know they wanted to target Americans,” said the source, who asked not to be named. “It’s clear they had quite specific targets.”

Terror in Brussels: A Timeline of Horror
----------------------------------------
#### A breakdown of the locations in Tuesday’s terrorist attacks in Brussels.
na
!
A breakdown of the locations in Tuesday’s terrorist attacks in Brussels.CreditCredit...Belgian Federal Police, via Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
*   March 22, 2016
BRUSSELS — Bombs packed with nails terrorized Brussels on Tuesday in the deadliest assault on the European heartland since the Islamic State’s attacks on Paris four months ago, hitting the airport and subway system in coordinated strikes that were also claimed by the militant extremist group.
The bombings paralyzed Brussels, the headquarters of the European Union and NATO, prompted international travel warnings to avoid Belgium and reverberated across the Atlantic to the United States, where New York and other major cities raised terrorism threat levels. Anxieties intensified about the inability to prevent mass killings at relatively unprotected places.
At least 30 people were killed by two blasts at the Brussels airport departure area around 8 a.m. and one in a subway station shortly after 9. The police found at least one other unexploded bomb in a search of a Brussels house hours later.
And Europe’s most wanted person suddenly became an unidentified man in a white coat and dark hat seen pushing a luggage cart in an airport surveillance photo taken just before the bombings. Two other men in the photo, each wearing a black glove on his left hand, were identified by Belgian prosecutors as suspected suicide bombers who appeared to have died in the explosions.
“To those who have chosen to be the barbaric enemies of liberty, of democracy, of fundamental values, I want to say with the greatest strength that we will remain assembled and united,” the Belgium prime minister, Charles Michel, said at a news conference Tuesday evening, declaring a three-day mourning period.
